3.name: imperative
3.description: type of programming paradigm in computer science

4.name: concurrent object-oriented
4.description: programming paradigm that combines object-oriented programming (OOP) together with concurrency

5.name: constraint
5.description: programming paradigm wherein relations between variables are stated in the form of constraints

6.name: object-oriented
6.description: programming paradigm based on the concept of objects

7.name: parallel
7.description: programming paradigm in which many calculations or the execution of processes are carried out simultaneously

9.name: reflective
9.description: ability of a process to examine and modify itself

10.name: visual
10.description: computer programming language to create programs by manipulating program elements graphically

11.name: constraint logic
11.description: Programming paradigm which combines logic programming and constraint satisfaction

13.name: declarative
13.description: programming paradigm that expresses the logic of a computation without describing its control flow

15.name: reactive
15.description: programming paradigm focused on data flow and change propragation

16.name: concurrent
16.description: form of computing in which several computations are executing during overlapping time periods

17.name: synchronous
17.description: programming paradigm supported by synchronous programming languages

19.name: agent-oriented
19.description: programming paradigm centred on the concept of software agents

20.name: array
20.description: programming paradigm that generalize operations on scalars to apply transparently to higher-dimensional arrays

22.name: dataflow
22.description: programming paradigm that models program as a directed graph of data flow between operations

24.name: functional reactive
24.description: programming paradigm for reactive programming using key features of functional programming

26.name: generic
26.description: way of designing and writing programs where algorithms are written in terms of parametric types enabling easy reuse

28.name: logic
28.description: programming paradigm based on formal logic

29.name: purely functional
29.description: programming paradigm that treats all computation as the evaluation of mathematical functions

33.name: stack-oriented
33.description: programming paradigm that relies on a stack machine model

36.name: structured
36.description: programming paradigm aimed at improving clarity, quality, and development time by using control structures
